build/chain-abstraction/chain-signatures.title: Chain Signatures
build/chain-abstraction/chain-signatures.description: Chain signatures enable NEAR accounts, including smart contracts, to sign and execute transactions across many blockchain protocols.

build/chain-abstraction/data-availabilit.title: Rollup Data Availability
build/chain-abstraction/data-availabilit.description: Utilizing NEAR as storage data availability with a focus on lowering rollup DA fees.

build/chain-abstraction/fastauth-sdk.title: FastAuth SDK
build/chain-abstraction/fastauth-sdk.description: FastAuth is a key management system that allows users to recover or sign-up for a NEAR account using their email address. Furthermore, it allows to subsidize gas for a certain smart contract, so users can interact with it without having to fund their account.

build/chain-abstraction/meta-transaction.title: Building a Meta Transaction Relayer
build/chain-abstraction/meta-transaction.description: Relayers serve to delegate gas fees to a web service, allowing users to transact on NEAR without the need to acquire the token themselves while still retaining the security of signing their own transactions. This guide will lead you through the components necessary to construct a relayer capable of handling meta transactions.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Gas Station Contract
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: The multichain gas station smart contract accepts payments in NEAR tokens in exchange for gas funding on non-NEAR foreign chains. Part of the NEAR Multichain effort, it works in conjunction with the MPC recovery service to generate on-chain signatures.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Relayer Server
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: The Multichain Relayer Server facilitates cross-chain transactions and enables Chain Abstraction.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Relayer and Gas Station example
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: In this article you'll learn how to run end-to-end tests on the entire Multichain Relayer system.

build/chain-abstraction/nft-chain-keys.title: NFT Chain Keys Smart Contract
build/chain-abstraction/nft-chain-keys.description: The NFT Chain Keys smart contract makes the ownership of remote accounts both provable and transferrable. This new paradigm allows you to create new end-user experiences that leverage provable and transferrable remote accounts as a core primitive.

build/chain-abstraction/what-is.title: What is Chain Abstraction?
build/chain-abstraction/what-is.description: The idea behind chain abstraction is quite simple: blockchain technology should be abstracted away from the user experience. In other words, people should not realize when they are using a blockchain, nor which blockchain they are using.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/best.description: In this article you can find suggested best practices when building blockchain indexers using QueryAPI.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/how-.description: QueryApi is a streaming indexer implementation that executes custom indexing logic written by developers on the NEAR blockchain.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/inde.description: QueryAPI is a fully managed service that allows you to create and manage indexers on-chain seamlessly.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/intr.title: QueryAPI Overview
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/intr.description: Near QueryAPI is a fully managed solution to build indexer functions, extract on-chain data, store it in a database, and be able to query it using GraphQL endpoints.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/migr.title: Migrate from NEAR Lake framework
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/migr.description: NEAR QueryAPI is currently under development. Users who want to test-drive this solution need to be added to the allowlist before creating or forking QueryAPI indexers.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/quer.title: Accessing and Querying Historical data
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/quer.description: In this article, you'll find a high-level overview about the two most common use-cases for blockchain indexing, and how they can be solved using NEAR QueryAPI and BigQuery.

build/data-infrastructure/what-is.title: What is Data Infrastructure?
build/data-infrastructure/what-is.description: NEAR offers ready-to-use solutions to access and monitor on-chain data easily. This is very useful to automate actions based on specific events, cache data to reduce latency, gather usage data of the blockchain, and even study user preferences.

build/near-components/anatomy/bos-compon.title: Historical data
build/near-components/anatomy/bos-compon.description: Building components that handle historical blockchain data require dedicated solutions that manage the data and reduce the latency of requests, as it's not possible to scan the whole blockchain when a user makes a request.

build/near-components/anatomy/social.title: Social Interactions
build/near-components/anatomy/social.description: NEAR components can natively communicate with the SocialDB smart contract (currently deployed at social.near).

build/near-components/anatomy/state.description: Borrowing from React, Near Components use hooks such as useState and useEffect to handle the state's logic, and props to receive parameters.

build/near-components/bos-gateway.description: In order to use the components you create in a WebApp you need to use what is known as the NEAR VM. This virtual machine helps you to easily fetch components from the blockchain and transform them into executable code.

build/near-components/what-is.description: NEAR Components are a new way to build web applications. They are composable, reusable and decentralized.

build/primitives/dao.title: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations
build/primitives/dao.description: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) are self-organized groups that form around common purposes. Membership, decision making, and funding are coordinated by publicly voting on proposals through a smart contract.

build/welcome.title: Build on NEAR
build/welcome.description: Welcome! Here you will find all the information on what you can build on NEAR and how to build it. Do not worry if you are new to Web3 or Blockchain, we are here to guide you through the process of learning.

concepts/abstraction/mpc.title: Multi-Party Computation (MPC)
concepts/abstraction/mpc.description: MPC, or multi-party computation, is about how multiple parties can do shared computations on private inputs without revealing the private data.

concepts/abstraction/relayers.title: Relayers
concepts/abstraction/relayers.description: A relayer is a simple web service that receives signed transactions from NEAR users, and relays them to the network while attaching tokens to sponsor their GAS expenses. This can be useful to create applications in which the users are not required to purchase NEAR in order to be able to transact. In this document we present a high-level overview on how relayers work. Please check the build a relayer page if you want to learn how to build your own relayer.

concepts/protocol/access-keys.title: Access Keys
concepts/protocol/access-keys.description: In all blockchains, users control their accounts by holding a private key (a secret only they know) and using it to sign transactions.

concepts/protocol/account-id.title: Address (Account ID)
concepts/protocol/account-id.description: NEAR accounts are identified by a unique address, which take one of two forms:

concepts/protocol/account-model.title: NEAR Accounts
concepts/protocol/account-model.description: Users participate in the NEAR ecosystem through their NEAR accounts. These accounts are identified by a unique address, can optionally hold a smart contract, and are controlled through Access Keys.

concepts/protocol/gas.title: Gas (Execution Fees)
concepts/protocol/gas.description: On every transaction the NEAR network charges a tiny fee known as gas. This fee is a simple mechanism that allows us to:

concepts/protocol/smartcontract.title: Smart Contract
concepts/protocol/smartcontract.description: Smart contracts are pieces of executable code that live in a NEAR account. They can store data, perform transactions in the accountâ€™s name, and expose methods so other accounts can interact with them.

concepts/protocol/transaction-anatomy.title: Anatomy of a Transaction
concepts/protocol/transaction-anatomy.description: A transaction is a request from a user to the network to perform a set of actions. To create a transaction, the user must specify the following fields:

concepts/protocol/transaction-execution.title: Lifecycle of a Transaction
concepts/protocol/transaction-execution.description: Transactions are constructed by users to express the intent of performing actions in the network. Once in the network, transactions are converted into Receipts, which are messages exchanged between network nodes.

concepts/protocol/transactions.title: Transactions
